texts.textentryhtml: Lonnie Holley, the artist, Birmingham, Alabama, sold; to William S. Arnett, Atlanta, Georgia, gift; to Souls Grown Deep Foundation, Atlanta, Georgia, sold; to Princeton University Art Museum, 2021.
texts.remarks: as per acquisition proposal. format amended. AP

texts.textentryhtml:
“I dig through what other people have thrown away . . . to get to the gold of it—to know that grandmother had that skillet and stood over that heat preparing that meal, so when I go home with that skillet, I’ve got grandmother.”

Lonnie Holley

Holley combines found objects into evocative assemblages that point simultaneously toward ancestral and art historical heritages. In The Gold at Grandmother’s Post, the artist hangs quilting fabric from the frame of a bedpost mounted on a washboard as a tribute to the generations of quilt-makers in his family. Loosely anthropomorphic, the assemblage also contains a figurative painting of two conversing faces that suggests the artwork’s status as a conversation among various materials, techniques, and traditions.

displaymaker: Lonnie Holley, born 1950, Birmingham, AL; active Birmingham
